title: Introduction to Urban Studies
description: This course examines the historical evolution of urban spaces from a cross-cultural perspective. The course discusses the importance of cities to the economic, cultural, and political well-being of modern societies and examines how forces such as industrialization, globalization and urbanization, among others, have affected the structure and functions of cities. Seminal theories and recent discourses in urban studies are discussed to examine how and why cities develop and change and the various roles stakeholders have played in the course of urban developments.
outcome: After taking this course, students should be able to: 1. Compare and contrast different schools of thoughts in analyzing and explaining urban developments; 2. Identify the specificities of urban development in Hong Kong vis-à-vis urban studies theories generated from other urban contexts; 3. Evaluate the roles of the state, the market and civil society in shaping urban transformations;  4. Identify the key elements of urban form and the forces of its transformation; and 5. Develop independent and critical thinking in applying theories to analyse concrete urban phenomena.
syllabus: 1. Introduction: What is ‘urban’? 2. Reading urban forms 3. Evolution of urban forms 4. City as a growth machine? 5. Socio-spatial polarization 6. Privatization of public space 7. title: Urban Studies in a Nutshell
description: This course is designed to introduce students to the multidisciplinary nature of urban studies. Students will learn the evolution of thoughts related to urban studies. And through local and overseas case studies, the instructors will investigate with students the social, economic, environmental and political aspects of urban development issues and their relationships with urban planning and design. Students will be encouraged to apply what they have learned to analyse an aspect of urban development in Hong Kong.

title: Introduction to Spatial Planning
description: This course aims to develop a basic level of spatial planning literacy among urban studies students. The course is divided into three modules: contemporary issues in spatial planning, the history and evolution of spatial planning and spatial planning as a process; and contemporary issues in spatial planning. Through various case studies, the course sensitizes students to various pertinent spatial planning issues in the specific institutional and legal context of Hong Kong.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to: 1. To develop a basic level of spatial planning literacy for life-long learning, appreciation and contribution to the urban realm. 2. To develop skills in conducting a spatial planning process. 3. To differentiate and critique good planning processes and outcomes from less desirable ones. 4. To develop a capacity to contribute creatively to sustainable spatial planning and development.

Climate change, resilient cities and spatial planning 5. Planning for spatial development 6. History of spatial planning 7. Spatial planning system and hierarchy of plans 8. Envisioning, planning goals and objectives 9. Plan generation 10. Plan evaluation 11. Impact assessments 12. Decision making 13. Plan implementation

title: Foundation of Digital Techniques for Urban Planning and Design
description: Digital media and computer-aided design techniques for urban planning and design are the foci of this course. Several computer-aided tools for urban analysis, design exploration, digital modelling and representation, professional drafting, information and concept visualization, and model making are introduced through lectures and tutorials covering history, conceptual usage, and practical skill of digital techniques. Participants must supplement lectures and tutorials by completing the relevant software tutorials on their own. The learning objective of this course is to apply and transfer skills to a variety of analytical and design tasks.

Recognise, comprehend and master the complexity of three-dimensional spatial setting.5. Apply computer-aided design skills on tasks relevant to urban planning and urban design.6. Analyse an urban design project, with considerable complexity, and communicate ideas visually

title: Field Studies
description: Field teaching is an integral part in the study of the urban world, which gives students an opportunity to understand the real-world situations and to supplement what they have learnt from the lectures. This course is designed in the format of a study trip in Hong Kong or a big overseas city. The objectives are three-fold: (1) to introduce students to different techniques in the collection of field data; (2) to help students identify, understand and explain urban problems; and (3) to provide an opportunity for students to work as a team in problem-solving. Students are required to participate actively in all activities throughout the study trip and to submit an individual report afterwards.

title: Belt and Road for Collaborative Modernization
description: (UGEC2917 is double-coded with URSP2010.)  The Belt and Road initiative (BRI) refers to the Silk Road Economic Belt and the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road. It is a significant development strategy proposed by the Chinese Government spanning approximately 60 countries in Asia, Eastern Europe, Middle East and Africa, with a total population of 4.4 billion. This initiative takes advantage of global transportation routes, core cities, and key ports to build international economic co-operation corridors. The effective operation and management of the BRI require collaboration among a broad range of disciplines comprising civil engineering, material science, government operations, economics and finance, social and political science, and environmental science. A critical and multi-disciplinary understanding of the BRI can provide insights into basic requirements, geopolitical impact, physical barriers, and sustainability potential of the infrastructural projects it proposes to undertake and help relevant stakeholders address large-scale and complex challenges in the lifecycle management of those infrastructure projects. This course involves forward-looking perspectives to assess, predict, influence and enhance the in/direct network effects and benefits of the BRI on the cities, urban systems and peoples of the Belt and Road region.
outcome: (1)    To explain the historical, economic and geopolitical background of the Belt and Road Initiative; (2)    To analyze economic, social, environmental, cultural and political forces, structures and processes associated with the Belt and Road Initiative; (3)    To evaluate the built environment and urban issues of Eurasian cities and how these may be improved by appropriate integration into the Belt and Road infrastructure; (4)    To apply Hong Kong’s world-class urban management practices to help the Belt and Road countries to maximize the benefits of network externality effects; (5)    To simulate and predict multi-scale spatial economic and urban outcomes of the Belt and Road infrastructure investments. (6)    To synthesize intercultural and global perspectives and to recommend ways to foster international cooperation, cultural diversity and integration.

imperial histories and ambitions informing the initiative. 4.       Eastern and Western Perspectives: the opportunities and challenges arising from Belt and Road Initiative with reference to the European Recovery Program; the geopolitical theories of Alfred Mahan, Halford Mackinder and Henry Kissinger; the philosophy of Confucius and Taoists.   Facilities Connectivity 5.       Construction Management in BRI countries: risk management in international construction joint ventures and overseas development institute; large-scale transnational high-speed railway construction projects. 6.       Green and Sustainable Urbanization: In search of better livability in BRI cities: Liveability in dense and vertical cities; green finance; carbon auditing and carbon trading; green strategies for achieving sustainable development goals.   Unimpeded Trade 7.       Trading, Logistic, and Professional Service: Hong Kong as regional BRI centre for trading, logistic and professional services; manufacture shifting and upgrading experience in ASEAN economies. 8.       The Energy Market: energy market opportunities and uncertainties in Northeast, Southeast, Central Asia and Africa; global oil and gas markets; renewable and sustainable energy goals.   Financial Integration 9.       The Bond Market: infrastructure financing; international bond market and Hong Kong’s debt market; corporate social responsibility on Green Bond Issuance; the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank and the Silk Road Fund. 10.    International Settlement: currency wars and special drawing rights; consumerism and RMB internationalization; Hong Kong as the offshore RMB centre; the New Development Bank.   Regional Responses 11.    Middle East: geopolitics and energy nexus; religious and national concerns. 12.    Central and Eastern Europe: rail and maritime connectivities; integrating trade and resisting xenophobia. 13.    India: regional rivalry, economic integration and border disputes

title: (Re) Claiming the City
description: (UGED2922 is double-coded with URSP2020.) Increasingly uneven and intensified processes of urbanization simultaneously generate serious challenges and exciting opportunities for urban populations across the globe. Contemporary cities are as much spaces of resonance, innovation, and emancipation as sites of violence, pollution, and alienation. This course revolves around the distinctive rhythms, experiences, and dynamics of urban life. What gives urban living its distinct characteristics? What current social, economic, and political problems deserve the attention of urban inhabitants? Which issues generate the greatest discord and motivate full coordination among different actors involved in governing cities? As urban life is characterized by both cosmopolitan conviviality and immense inequality, in this course students will learn about different modes of coexistence and exclusion in contemporary cities. Globalizing forms of urban protest arising from struggles over urban resources, space, and decision-making mechanisms will be investigated. By highlighting the complex and contested dynamics of urban life, the course will help students situate and interpret their everyday urban experiences at the intersection of multiple and interconnected flows, networks, and scales that are produced by the city and that produce it.
outcome: After taking this course, students will be able to:  Comprehend general debates, themes, and concepts in critical urban theory,  Apply key concepts and theories reflexively to their own experiences in the city,  Gain a critical understanding of urban politics, social movements, and public space,  Use qualitative methods as a tool for interpreting the struggles over urban governance, contested claims to urban space, and symbolic construction of city as text.

title: Urban Sustainability
description: This course explores theories and practices pertaining to urban sustainability, focusing on the fundamental issue that gives rise to the notion of sustainability—the integrity of the Earth’s life-supporting system. It examines global and local environmental issues, as well as consequential socioeconomic problems, arising from urban development and continuous urban growth. It also explores existing and emerging approaches to urban sustainability. Throughout the course, students will be challenged to contemplate on the core of the quest of urban sustainability—the relationship between humans and nature.
outcome: After taking this course, students should be able to: 1.recognize the inter-connectedness of various sectors in urban development and the importance of integrated and holistic thinking in pursuing urban sustainability; 2.explain and analyze how socioeconomic factors affect the sustainability of a place; 3.generalize existing and emerging approaches to urban sustainability; 4.compare and contrast the roles of the government, the private sector and the civil society in moving towards urban sustainability; and 5.develop a capacity to diagnose urban sustainability issues and offer plausible solutions.
syllabus: 1: Defining sustainability 2: Environmental problems of urban development 3: Urban metabolism 4: Urban air quality 5: Urban climate 6: Urban ecology and hydrology 7: Sustainability issues in Hong Kong 8: Ecosystem services and sustainable cities 9: Urban resilience to natural hazards and climate change 10: Design and planning approaches to urban sustainability 11: Socio-economic issues in urban sustainability 12: Challenges in moving towards sustainable cities in Asia & Concluding remarks

title: Urban Economic Studies
description: Urban economic studies examines the locational choices of firms and households and their effects on the formation of cities of different sizes. The course investigates the positive and negative externalities of cities and challenges students to apply basic economic principles to resolve urban issues.
outcome: After taking this course, students should be able to: 1. Compare and contrast patterns of spatial arrangements of firm and households in cities; 2. Identify externalities arising from the spatial arrangements of cities; 3. Develop independent and critical thinking in evaluating existing related urban economic issues; and 4. Use economic concepts to formulate appropriate public policies to address urban issues.
syllabus: Key topics to be included: • Urban economic development: determinants and processes • Spatial arrangements of firms and households:  o Land markets in cities  o Development of firms in cities  o Housing markets in cities  o Urban transportation system • Positive and negative externalities of cities of various scales  o Economy of scale and urban efficiency  o Urban poverty and polarization  o Gentrification  o Congestion and pollution • Public policy responses  o Government policies  o Local public finance  o Tax issues

title: Urban Design and Place Making
description: This course is concerned with the multidisciplinary field and practice of urban design. It includes a review of historical approaches to urban design and current movements in the field, as well as place making, theories of good city form, scales of urban design, implementation approaches, and challenges and opportunities for the discipline.
outcome: After taking this course, students should be able to :  1. understand urban design as a multidisciplinary field; 2. recognize the contribution of urban design to the creation or enhancement of urban places; 3. develop creative sensitivity for the qualities of place; 4. analyze and evaluate how urban design projects can facilitate and shape community based urban processes; 5. compare and contrast concepts and positions in urban design and place theory; and 6. reflect on contemporary opportunities and challenges of urban design.
syllabus: • What is urban design and what are the activities of urban designers?  • How can we sense and evaluate urban design and urban places? • How can urban design facilitate participatory urban processes? • What are contemporary limitations and challenges of urban design? • How can urban designers develop approaches to address urgent contemporary issues?

title: Studies of Cities in Comparative Perspective
description: This course introduces students to the studies of comparative urbanism. Urban studies have strong west-centric and modernist biases that designate specific cities as universal models for city-proper status and/or as harbingers of new urban forms. Drawing on postcolonial and poststructuralist critiques, the course aims at aiding future urbanists to explore a world of cities beyond developmentalist perspectives and the fetishization of novelty. The students will instead learn to become aware of and analyze the complex and interconnected manifestations of urban forms and experiences across different times and places.
outcome: After taking the course, students should be able to:  1. Gain knowledge of various concepts, standards and typologies of comparative urbanism;  2. Critically engage developmentalist perspectives when comparing cities; 3. Develop methods and frameworks to explain differences and similarities between urban forms, experiences and spaces; 4. Analyze the complex ways in which various configurations of urban life relate to specific historical events, cultural influences, institutional effects, political agency and informal processes.

title: Field Studies I
description: Field teaching is an integral part in the study of the urban world, which gives students an opportunity to understand the real-world situations and to supplement what they have learnt from the lectures. This course is designed in the format of a study trip in Hong Kong or a big overseas city. The objectives are three-fold: (1) to introduce students to different techniques in the collection of field data; (2) to help students identify, understand and explain urban problems; and (3) to provide an opportunity for students to work as a team in problem-solving. Students are required to participate actively in all activities throughout the study trip and to submit an individual report afterwards.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to: •apply urban studies, planning and design theories and analytical tools in the field study; •compare and contrast context-based societal issues and formulate related research questions; •reflect on the diversified interests of various local stakeholders; •analyse urban issues with reference to theories and international practices; and •formulate practical solutions considering local constraints and opportunities.
syllabus: A number of study themes will be proposed for the field study. Students will be organized into groups to undertake research during the field study.
required_readings: Will be assigned according to the destination of the field trip.
recommended_readings: Will be assigned according to the destination of the field trip.

title: Essentials of Urban Planning
description: This course aims to develop a basic level of urban literacy among students as urbanites in Hong Kong, Asia’s World City. Not only will students appreciate urban planning as a process that involves various stakeholders, they will also learn to compare and contrast different approaches of urban planning. The course sensitizes students to various pertinent urban planning issues in the specific context of Hong Kong such as what constitutes the public interest, the role between knowledge and power, multiculturalism, urban design in the public realm and people’s right and obligations in the course of urban development and planning.

title: Digital Techniques for Urban Planning and Design
description: Digital design media and geographic information systems for urban planning and design are core topics addressed in this course. Digital instruments for analyzing, drafting, modeling, testing, visualization, and fabrication are introduced through lectures covering theoretical concepts and practical skill building exercises. Participants must supplement lectures and tutorials by completing the relevant software tutorials on their own. The learning objective of this course is to apply and transfer skills to a variety of analytical and design tasks.
outcome: After taking this course, students should be able to: - Learn and transfer skills in the use of digital software for visualization, analyses and design;  - Apply these skills for a range of tasks in the field of urban planning and design; and - Understand basic knowledge of current digital environments and trends and have the ability for continuing self-learning.
syllabus: The aim of this course is for participants to become eloquent in the use of digitally aided techniques for urban planning and design. Participants shall be able to explore ideas, analyze spatial data, and present and communicate design concepts electronically by employing a variety of digital and mixed media. Participants who complete this course will have a broad knowledge of various computing instruments and techniques for analyses and design. They will have sufficient practical skills allowing the immediate application in their urban design studios and other courses.
required_readings: Respective software manuals and tutorials of each software application presented in the course.
recommended_readings: Respective software manuals and tutorials of each software application presented in the course.

title: Urban Form, Sense of Place and Well-Being
description: Urbanisation has changed the natural landscape into human habitats, shaping people’s daily lives and their modes of interactions. Technological developments have allowed the human race to ‘overcome’ many environmental constraints and gradually people have developed their urban settlements for functional purposes, forgetting the important relationships between forms and people’s sense of well-being. The popularization of smartphones, internet and social media further disconnected people from experiencing a place fully. What are urban forms? How do urban forms affect our sense of a place? How is our sense of place related to our subjective sense of multi-faceted well-being? This course aims to equip students with an ability to understand and study the relationships of urban forms, sense of place and sense of well-being so that they can (re)create urban forms that are conducive to community sense of place and multi-faceted well-being.Through interactive class activities, the design and conduct of a team survey and individual essay writing, students learn not only about the importance of urban forms in shaping people’s sense of place and community and the multifaceted well-being, but also how to design a questionnaire survey to research and analyse their relationships and formulate suggestions to enhance the situation of local neighbourhoods.
outcome: After taking the course, students are expected to: 1. Compare and contrast various typologies of urban form and their relationships with people’s diversified sense of place/community and multifaceted well-being 2. Cultivate a capacity to differentiate desirable urban forms from less desirable ones for multifaceted well-being 3. Generalise the relationships among urban forms, sense of place and well-being 4. Identify principles that can create and design urban forms that promote better and strong sense of place and community

title: Recommoning
description: More than two centuries of market driven capitalist developments in various parts of the world have brought much progress to humankind, but such growth has also led to formidable global environmental and socio-economic challenges. This course attempts to rethink about economic developments that centre around the wellbeing of people and the environment. The course explores ways people across the globe are building community economies based on ethical concerns for more sustainable and equitable futures. It aims to provide the theoretical grounding to re-imagine economic development and practical skills in recommoning—organising community-based development interventions that promote the well-being of people, place and planet.
outcome: After taking the course, students should be able to: 1. appreciate the diversity of economic practices that are found locally and in other parts of the world 2. compare the different theoretical approaches used to frame these diverse economic practices 3. compare and contrast the ethical, ecological and equity concerns of different economic practices 4. analyse the contribution of diverse economic practices to more sustainable and equitable forms of development  5. identify the types of policies that might foster diverse economic practices that align with the principles of recommoning
syllabus: • What is development? • What is the economy? • Theoretical approaches to economic development • Surviving well • Distributing surplus • Encountering others • Re-commoning • Investing in futures • Policies for economic diversity • Case studies • Whither recommoning

title: Special Topics in Urban Studies I
description: This course provides an in-depth analysis of specific topics in urban studies that supplements other courses offered by the Programme. The topics selected are of great significance to urban development and planning. The content of the course will vary with the instructor. Important topics will include the theories and practices of urban development, planning and design.

title: Housing Issues and Policy
description: This course aims to engage students in understanding and analysing complex housing issues and to prepare them in identifying and formulating integrated policy options for the recognised problems. Students will explore issues and policy realms related to different forms and categories of housing provided by the public and private sectors in specific socio-economic contexts. They will be encouraged to explore sustainable policy options and design to meet the housing needs of different socio-economic groups.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to: •Compare and contrast various approaches to the provision of housing as one of the human rights or as part of the market mechanisms; •identify, analyse and explain factors related to housing provision and behavior; •reflect on the various socio-economic, environmental, physical and governance aspects of housing provision at different geographical levels; •generanlize and reflect on the theoretical issues related to housing provision; and •develop capacity in creating and designing a sustainable housing policy.

title: Urban Design Studio
description: This course is an introductory-level design studio, in which students learn fundamental urban design concepts and tools for designing the urban built environment. The students work closely with the instructor to develop an urban design scheme for a study site, learning how to strategically organize major urban design elements, such as buildings, streets and open spaces, and infrastructure, taking into account a plethora of associated socioeconomic and environmental factors. The students go through a series of exercises, including precedent studies, site survey, site analysis, mapping, programming, model making, conceptualization, visualization, oral presentation, etc.
outcome: 1. To develop fundamental design skills in formulating an urban design scheme that incorporates major physical elements of the city, i.e. buildings, open spaces, streets, transport, and infrastructure, to meet the economic/ social/environmental needs of the community under the framework of SDGs (particularly SDG 11).2. To identify issues/problems/opportunities of the study site and resolve into creative urban design proposals.3. To apply verbal and visual communication skills for effective representation of urban design concepts / solutions.4. To demonstrate critical thinking in urban design, urban management, and community building.

title: Sustainable Urban Transport
description: Sustainability issues are increasingly addressed in the planning and development of urban transport. Our understanding of sustainable development has changed the ways we handle passenger and freight transport. This course will introduce urban transportation issues from the social, economic, and environmental perspectives. Transport policies, programs, and tools for sustainable communities will be introduced. While sustainable mobility and freight movement will be discussed in the course, the focus will be on issues related to personal mobility and accessibility.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to: •understand current challenges in urban transport; •understand the sustainable planning process; •identify the economic indicators, social indicators, and environmental indicators for transport planning; •analyze proposals for individual cities and communities; and •evaluate transport policy recommendations.

title: Essentials of the Land Development Process
description: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of a land development process, including programme planning, budgeting and financing, site selection and property acquisition, regulatory clearance, design, construction and completion. title: Field Studies II
description: The field studies concentrate on the understanding of places through direct observation and personal experience. The course gives opportunity to study specific urban settings and their spatial and cultural contexts. Students analyse on-site the impact of design and planning decisions on liveability, vitality and sense of place. The course trains techniques of documentation and analysis such as mapping, drawing and photographing. The field studies are conducted in Hong Kong, mainland China or overseas according to specific themes.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to: • Apply urban studies, planning and design theories and analytical tools in the field study. compare and contrast context-based societal issues and formulate related research questions • Reflect on the diversified interests of various local stakeholders • Analyse urban issues with reference to theories and international practices • Formulate practical solutions considering local constraints and opportunities

title: Designing Smart Cities
description: Are smart cities just about deploying technologies to improve a city’s infrastructure? Does the concept of ‘smart city’ go beyond improving hard-ware, combating climate change and closing the gaps of socio-economic disparities? Students in this course will review how smart cities in other parts of the world are designed. With a synthesized framework on the various aspects of smart city developments, students will engage different stakeholders in a district to audit their understanding of the utility of different smart technologies and examine what can be done to improve their life and livelihood. Based on the findings, students have to design a basket of measures to nurture a smart community.
outcome: After taking the course, students are expected to: 1. compare and contrast different modes of planning and designing smart cities 2. anlayse and project development of smart technologies and their applications in the context of Hong Kong 3. develop skills in engaging the general public to evaluate their understanding and demand for smart technologies 4. revisit the Hong Kong Planning Standards and Guidelines, relevant ordinances or even design strategies, policies, institutions or measures to enable the use of technologies in meeting people’s daily needs and creating smart communities

title: Urban Regeneration
description: Urban regeneration is important for most developed cities including Hong Kong given the lack of developable land in urban area. Urban regeneration offers some unique opportunities for the re-planning of some developed space for a better environment, where architectural conservation, landscape improvement, and better urban design can be implemented. However, owing to the many stakeholders, economic reasons and the diversified concerns, the process is also creating major debates in the community.Besides the deliberation on the theoretical concepts, the course will go through the technical process of urban regeneration which includes land use planning, architectural conservation, landscape and environmental improvement and urban design. This will enable students to understand the mechanism of urban transformation process thoroughly and may inspire them to further their studies in specific professional fields.On the social side, redevelopment as a major tool of urban regeneration often disturbs and uproots existing residents, small local businesses and their social networks. Together with the issue of compensation this has been causing major public concerns. The issues are further complicated by the recent debate on the social responsibilities and economic sustainability of the Urban Renewal Authority. This course aims not only at letting students understand the process of urban regeneration but their ability to analyze and assess the issues objectively and critically.
outcome: After taking the course, students are expected to  - Understand the core concepts and theories of urban regeneration;  - Understand the theories, functions and opportunities of land use planning, architectural conservation, landscape improvement and urban design in the process of Urban Regeneration;  - Apply theoretical and practical perspectives to analyze the multi-disciplinary function involved in urban regeneration cases;  - Analyze and evaluate the interests and concerns of different stakeholders and the disputes in the role of the URA and the Government in the process of Urban Regeneration; and  - Understand the impact of Urban Regeneration on the community and the society at large; and  - Generate own perspectives and interest in the subject of urban regeneration, land use planning, architectural conservation, urban and landscape design, and social impact of the process.

title: Urban Studies Capstone Thesis I
description: Students are required to produce a final Capstone Thesis related to their areas of concentration under the guidance of their supervisors. Students are expected to apply appropriate skills and research methodologies to comprehend and analyse the causes of the identified urban problem and appraise and formulate creative and sustainable policy, planning, design or management solutions. title: Urban Planning Theory and Practice
description: This course aims to engage students to critically reflect on urban planning theories and practices as processes shaped by different stakeholders in varying institutional settings. Students are encouraged to compare and contrast various planning theories and their implications for the possible value positions and practical actions by the government, the market and the civil society groups in the planning process. They are expected to apply the theoretical perspectives to analyse and evaluate existing planning practices and suggest ways to improve them.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected:  •To compare and contrast the various approaches to interpret the functions of urban planning and their implications on the roles of the government, the market and the civil society in the planning process; •To identify and reflect on the value and theoretical issues involved in the distribution of resources through urban planning within an institutional setting; and •To recognize the importance of urban planning theories and the formulation of their own value positions in evaluating the actually existing urban planning mechanisms and in guiding practices.
